repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Financial Institutions Development
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Financial
            Institutions Development Loan is rated as satisfactory with
            sustainability likely. Key lessons learned follow. The
            implementation of reforms in the banking sector was
            successful due to successive Government's ownership of
            the program and the commitment to move to a market based
            economy. The twinning worked well in this case and proved to
            be an effective mechanism for transferring know-how.
            Important aspects for successful twinning are clear
            expectations, sound work schedules, realistic pace, close
            and candid monitoring, and the full involvement of senior
            management of the local bank. Institution building is a
            medium to long-term process requiring significant change in
            minds and systems and significant training (the Bank was
            over ambitious in estimating the time needed to implement
            the comprehensive policy and institutional development
            reforms). Bank's procurement procedures were perceived
            as being complex, rigid, and not fully suitable for dealing
            with procurement of complex software based information
            technology. In hindsight, it may have been better to have
            stayed with the original project proposal to finance the
            basic, initial automation needs of the banks and leave the
            financing of fully integrated systems for the future, at
            which time they could have been financed directly by the
            banks which would have had more flexibility to choose the
            supplier and approaches to fit their individual needs.

728328.trustfund: TF025600-PHRD-FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS DEVELOPMENT,TF020290-IRISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF023660-DUTCH CTF FOR EASTERN EUROPE

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - The Polish banking industry
            twinning program

abstracts.cdata!:
As part of its financial sector reform
            program, the polish government has embarked on a set of
            innovative twinning arrangements between Polish state, owned
            banks and West European commercial banks, comprising
            comprehensive, two to three year institutional development
            programs covering all aspects of banking. This article
            explores how the pairs of Polish and west, European twinning
            banks were matched, why the concept of twinning was chosen,
            rather than more traditional technical assistance (TA)
            arrangements, what the twinning arrangements were to
            achieve, the initial results, and lessons to be learned from
            the Polish experience for applying the concept of twinning
            to other Eastern European and Former Soviet Union (FSU) countries.

Poland - The Polish banking industry

5082106.trustfund: TF025600-PHRD-FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS DEVELOPMENT,TF023660-DUTCH CTF FOR EASTERN EUROPE,TF020290-IRISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND
5082106.majtheme: Economic management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Financial Institutions Development
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are
            to support financial sector development as a key element of
            the Government's Economic Transformation Program
            through:  (i) actions on the policy, regulatory, and
            institutional fronts; and (ii) modernization and ultimate
            privatization of existing banks. The project includes two
            components:  (i) a quick-disbursing policy component; and
            (ii) an institutional development component.  The major
            policy reforms urgently needed to permit a rapid transition
            toward a modern market-oriented, mostly private, financial
            system must be accompanied by significant, concerted efforts
            to develop efficient institutions and skilled staff.  There
            is consequently a strong interrelation between the two
            components and the success of the reform program will
            closely depend on their timely joint implementation.  The
            policy component is articulated around four elements: (i)
            improvements of financial policies; (ii) modernization of
            banking legislation; (iii) bank restructuring; and (iv)
            development of financial markets.  The core of the
            institutional development component relates to a
            comprehensive program of technical assistance and automation
            programs for banks aimed at their institutional
            strengthening and privatization.
